questions.text: What classification for External Branch of Superior Laryngeal Nerve is shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the relation of External branch of Superior laryngeal nerve crossing the superior thyroid vessels near the upper pole of thyroid gland. There are variations in it, the most important classification of which is given by Cernea and colleagues. Friedmann and Kierner are other classifications for EBSLN.

Among these, Type 2B has the highest risk of getting injured.

choices.text: Left Hemithyroidectomy alone is an option
Total Thyroidectomy with Ipsilateral CCND (left Side)

questions.text: 40 female presented to your OPD with left side thyroid swelling of size around 1 cm. Basic thyroid function tests found to be normal and on evaluation with USG Neck & Thyroid - shows a single nodule of size 1.0 x 0.8 cm with mixed cystic and solid components and no evidence of neck nodes. So, a Guided FNA is done, for which the cytology picture is shown below. What is the further management for this patient?
questions.solution:
40 female with 1 cm thyroid nodule, with FNAC showing Nuclear grooving and Orphan annie eye nuclei diagnostic of Papillary carcinoma. For any thyroid malignancy, Total thyroidectomy is the treatment option. But this person does not have nodes, which means no need for Central compartment Neck Dissection.

But Sabiston says "Hemithyroidectomy can be safely done in selected cases of papillary carcinoma like Size < 1cm, Unifocal, no extrathyroidal extension, no neck nodes, no history of previous radiation".

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen with MEN2B
questions.solution:
MEN 2B or MEN 3 or Wagenmann Froeboese syndrome

C cell hyperplasia, MTC, adrenal medullary hyperplasia, pheochromocytomas, mucosal neuromas, skeletal abnormalities, ganglioneuromatoisis of GIT, marfanoid habitus.

choices.text: All parathyroids should be removed even if not diseased

questions.text: Following a Total thyroidectomy for MTC in a patient with MEN2A, True regarding parathyroids
questions.solution: Surgery for MTC in MEN syndromes mandates Total thyroidectomy with Prophylactic CCND with or without lateral neck dissection depending on nodal status. CCND puts parathyroids in danger due to vascular disruption. Hence parathyroids are autotransplanted into non dominant forearm in MEN 2A (due to fear of future parathyroid adenoma associated with it, which mandates resection)

questions.text: 45 male presenting to the surgery OPD with a swelling in the right lateral aspect of the neck with thyroid nodule of size 4x2 cm. Patient has no other symptoms except for hoarseness. FNA proved to be papillary thyroid carcinoma. What's the clinical staging?
questions.solution: In this question, the swelling in the lateral aspect of neck denoted cervical metastases, which according to Thyroid TNM staging is N1b. Hoarseness denotes infiltration of Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve, which means T4a Irrespective of the size of the tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is considered poor prognostic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Prognostic factors is given by several systems AMES, AGES and MACIS groups.

Age > 45 years, Male sex, Extrathyroidal invasion, Metastases and size > 5 cm

choices.text: Right Recurrent laryngeal Nerve has an oblique course
Superior Parathyroid gland is anterior to RLN
Non recurrent Laryngeal nerve is more common on Right side
Inferior thyroid veins drains into Brachiocephalic Veins

questions.text: Regarding Surgical anatomy of Thyroid gland, FALSE statement is
questions.solution:
Right Recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from right vagus around Right subclavian artery and has an oblique course in the neck to reach the larynx by running in proximity to thyroid gland, inferior thyroid artery.

Non recurrent laryngeal nerve is more common on the right side and associated with Aberrant Right subclavian artery from descending thoracic aorta.

Superior and middle thyroid veins drains into IJV and Inferior thyroid veins drains into Left brachiocephalic veins.

Superior parathyroid is posterior to RLN and inferior is anterior to RLN.

questions.text: All of the following are mechanisms of Hypercalcemia of Malignancy except
questions.solution:
There are three mechanisms by which hypercalcemia of malignancy occurs:

  1. Release of cytokines by osteolytic metastases,
  2. Tumor secretion of PTHrP, and
  3. Tumor production of calcitriol.

questions.text: TENIS Syndrome is associated with
questions.solution:
TENIS Syndrome is Thyroglobulin Elevation Negative Iodine Scintigraphy(TENIS) due to Truncated Expression of Na:I - Symporter (TENIS). Iodine cannot be taken inside thyroid cells and hence during follow up of patients with thyroid cancer, where there will be increased thyroglobulin but negative on Radioactive Iodine scan.

In such cases, PET Scan will be the modality of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for surgery in patients with asymptomatic PHPT?

choices.text: Simple mastectomy with RT to the axilla
NAC followed by MRN and ALND

questions.text: Treatment of a patient with occult breast cancer with N1 M0 is
questions.solution:
Occult breast cancer (OBC) is defined as isolated metastatic axillary lymphadenopathy with no palpable mass in the breast and no signs of primary breast cancer on mammography and no detected primary tumor outside the breast.

It is classified by the American Joint Committee on Cancer as T0N1-3M0 stage II-III. The current treatment options for T0N+ breast cancer include mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissections (ALND) with or without post-mastectomy radiation (BR) or ALND with whole-breast irradiation with or without lymph node irradiation.

questions.text: All of the following have cancer risk except
questions.solution: Cancer risk associated with Benign breast disorders and in situ malignancies

questions.text: Treatment for Duct Ectasia with Periductal Mastitis is
questions.solution:
For Duct ectasia - Treatment is Microdochectomy

For Periductal mastitis - Treatment is total duct excision or Hadfield operation

questions.text: 35 Female presented with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer, has a 2x2 cm lump in the right upper outer quadrant without any evidence of axillary nodes. Which of the following will be the treatment modality of choice?
questions.solution: Patient with high risk criteria like BRCA mutation carriers, family history of breast cancer, previous contralateral breast cancer all should undergo Modified radical mastectomy. BCS is a relative contraindication in such cases.

questions.text: Tumor markers used in monitoring breast cancers are all except
questions.solution:
The following tumor markers are useful in monitoring breast cancers

CEA, CA 15-3, CA 27.29.

CA 125 is useful in monitoring ovarian cancers.

choices.text: BCS + ALND + Oncoplastic Surgery + WBRT + Adjuvant therapies

questions.text: 40 female with a lump in the right breast lower quadrant of size 3x2cm with ipsilateral mobile axillary nodes. Core needle biopsy revealed ductal adenocarcinoma, ER+ve and HER2 -ve tumor. Ideal management in this situation is?
questions.solution: If the question had been tumor in the upper quadrant, there is no need for Oncoplastic surgery. Whenever the tumor is in lower quadrant, there is high chance of nipple distortion and poor cosmetic outcome, so an Oncoplastic Surgery is contemplated.

questions.text: All of the following flaps are used in breast reconstruction except
questions.solution: Following Breast surgeries, the reconstruction options will be using a LattismusDorsi flap (LD flap), TRAM flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Muscle), DIEP flap (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator flap). Obviously PMMC (Pectoralis Major MyoCutaneous flap) cannot be used.)

questions.text: BCS can still be a possibility in
questions.solution: BCS is not possible in Locally advanced and Metastatic breast cancers. Hence B, C and D are incorrect. T3N1 although a LABC disease, if Neoadjuvant chemotherapy has Complete Response, BCS is still a possibility. In such cases, Prechemo wire localization of the tumor is essential.

choices.text: Level III nodes includes Infraclavicular nodes
Halsteadian ligament is the superomedial limit of axillary dissection
Medial pectoral nerve is medial to lateral pectoral nerve
Intercostobrachial Nerve is usually sacrificed in MRM

questions.text: Regarding Surgical Anatomy of Breast, FALSE is
questions.solution: Medial pectoral nerve is lateral to Lateral pectoral nerve. Rest options are correct.

questions.text: Risk factors for Carcinoma Breast with high relative risk includes all EXCEPT
Banff criteria is used to diagnose
questions.solution:
CAN (Chronic Allograft Nephropathy) is the result of immunological and nonimmunological injury, including acute rejection episodes, hypoperfusion, ischaemia reperfusion, calcineurin toxicity, infection and recurrent disease.

Classification of CAN is histological using the Banff classification of renal allograft pathology with classic findings of interstitial fibrosis, tubular atrophy, glomerulosclerosis, fibrointimal hyperplasia and arteriolar hyalinosis.

questions.text: Warm Ischemia is seen in
questions.solution: Warm Ischemic Time denotes the time between cessation of blood supply to the organ and cold perfusate solution infusion to the organ. It is seen in Non-Heart Beating Donors or Donors after Cardiac Death. Ideally, it should be within 20 minutes to prevent increased risk of Rejection.

questions.text: All of the following are taken into account for organ transplantation EXCEPT
questions.solution: HLA compatibility is very essential as they are highly conserved polymorphic gene products which vary greatly within the species. ABO compatibility is also essential, as they are not only present on blood cells but also in other cells as well. Rh compatibility is not essential, as they are only related to blood cells.

questions.text: What does this picture depicts?
questions.solution: The picture shows specific immunity by CD4 T cells and causing parenchymal necrosis and it is an example of acute rejection. Acute rejection is the most common type of rejection and occurs most commonly within six months.

questions.text: Anti-CD 25 mab is
questions.solution: Basiliximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody targeted against CD 25 (IL-2 receptor) to block IL-2 mediated activation of T cells. It is a powerful induction agent used in induction phase of immunosuppression.

questions.text: Costimulatory molecules are all EXCEPT
questions.solution: For T cell response to occur, costimulation signals are also required for action. Costimulation is brought about by binding of CD 28 with CD 80/86 and CD 40 with CD 154.

questions.text: Which of the following prevents Reperfusion injury?
questions.solution: Organ preservative solutions contain several components, of which Potassium lactobionate and Raffinose prevents Reperfusion injury

questions.text: Mediator responsible for Chronic graft rejection is
questions.solution: Although the exact pathogenesis of chronic graft rejection is unknown or not well studied, several studies show there is increased amounts of TGF beta that has a causal role in chronic allograft rejection.

questions.text: Most common cause of graft failure in kidney transplant is
questions.solution:
Most common type of graft rejection is Acute rejection

Most common cause of chronic graft loss or graft failure is chronic rejection

questions.text: Maximum Warm Ischemia time acceptable for any organ donation is
questions.solution: Maximum warm ischemia time acceptable for any organ is 45 minutes.

questions.text: Maastricht classification is used in categorizing
questions.solution: DCD donors can be grouped according to the Maastricht classification* as follows:

choices.text: GCS less than 13 at any point

questions.text: NICE guidelines for CT in head injury includes
questions.solution:
NICE GUIDELINES FOR CT IN HEAD INJURY:

  • GCS <13 at any point
  • Deterioration of GCS over time
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Dangerous mechanism or antegrade amnesia >30 minutes
  • Mild injury in >65 years or Coagulopathy patients

questions.text: REBOA is an alternative for
questions.solution: REBOA – Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta – quicker, less invasive method of achieving aortic occlusion during initial resuscitation, providing another tool to combat early exsanguinating blood loss.

questions.text: What is Left sided medial visceral rotation?
questions.solution:
Left sided medial visceral rotation is called Mattox maneuver.  Here you are rotation all the left sided viscera medially.

Right sided medial visceral rotation is called Cattel Braasch maneuver.

questions.text: Blunt trauma to Portal Vein or Retrohepatic IVC considered under
questions.solution:
Zone I - Middle of Retroperitoneum (includes great vessels)

Zone II - Both right and left paracolic and renal regions (kidneys, adrenals)

Zone III - Pelvic

Zone IV - Retrohepatic IVC and portal vein regions (low pressure region) hence not explored.

questions.text: Latent period of Baudet is seen in
questions.solution:
Grading of Splenic injuries based on American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) guidelines from Grade I to Grade V.In low grade injuries, there will be initial bleeding and stops. But there will be delayed initiation of hemorrhage which can occur up to weeks after injury (Latent Period of Baudet)

The rate of rebleeding is 10.6%.

choices.text: Cross clamp of aorta done distal to inferior pulmonary ligament
Manual massage of heart done with single hand
Done in the Trauma bay itself and not in OR
Always uses a Left anterolateral thoracotomy incision in 5th ICS

questions.text: Regarding Emergency Resuscitative thoracotomy, FALSE statement is
questions.solution: Regarding Emergency Resuscitative Thoracotomy, it is done in the trauma bay itself, by making left anterolateral thoracotomy. It is done to evacuate blood clot from pericardium, manually massage the heart using clap hand technique (not single hand which cause perforation of atrium) and cross clamping of aorta done distal to inferior pulmonary ligament.

questions.text: All are needed in the management of Neuro Trauma EXCEPT

choices.text: Head injury in an RTA is an example
Lateral compression of pelvis from left sided impact in RTA is an example

questions.text: True statement regarding Overt Injuries is all EXCEPT
How many trained personnel required for LOG ROLL in a trauma patient?
questions.solution: LOG ROLL - to inspect the back. Done by 4 members. One member responsible for maintaining in line spinal stabilisation. Three other staff hold the patient steady through the turn and inspect and palpate the entire spine from occiput to sacrum.

choices.text: Tracheostomy is the surgical airway of choice in Upper airway injuries
Expanding Hematoma in Zone 2 needs Exploration immediately even when hemodynamically stable
Surgical access is very difficult in Zone 1
Antiplatelet therapy forms the mainstay in management of blunt cerebrovascular injuries

questions.text: Regarding Management of Neck Injuries, FALSE statement is
questions.solution: Zone III (from angle of mandible to base of skull) is least surgically accessible and not Zone I. Tracheostomy is the airway of choice in upper airway injury as cricothyroidotomy is not possible when major laryngotracheal fractures occur.  When there is expanding hematoma in zone II, exploration mandatory even when hemodynamically unstable as there is risk of carotid vessel injury.

choices.text: It is the result of Crush Injuries to Extremities
Fasciotomy is must where entrapment has occurred over 12 hours

questions.text: False statement regarding Crush Syndrome is
questions.solution: Crush injury occurs when a body part is subjected to heavy force or pressure, usually squeezed between two heavy or immobile objects. Management includes Aggressive fluid resuscitation with about 1 to 1.5L per hour till proper urine output is achieved. Then alkanisation of urine along with Alkaline mannitol diuresis is carried until there is no myoglobin in urine. Late Fasciotomy will only worsen the condition and not have benefit.

questions.text: Goals in the treatment of Secondary Brain Injury All EXCEPT

choices.text: Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma

questions.text: Expand FAST
questions.solution:
FAST (FOCUSSED ASSESSMENT WITH SONOGRAPHY for TRAUMA)

Used in all abdominal trauma patients whether hemodynamically stable or unstable.

It is a rapid bedside diagnostic procedure to identify any free fluid in abdomen (could not tell blood or ascitic fluid)

It is not 100% sensitive.

questions.text: The only differentiating feature of Tension pneumothorax from Simple Pneumothorax is
questions.solution: Hypotension is the only definitive feature of Tension pneumothorax and not even tracheal deviation, which can occur in massive simple pneumothorax

choices.text: N1 is single ipsilateral node measuring >3cm
N2b is multiple ipsilateral nodes, measuring >6cm
N2a is single ipsilateral node not more than 6cm

questions.text: According to AJCC TNM staging of Head and neck cancers, True statement regarding Nodal staging is
Type of melanoma that does not have lymphatic metastases is
questions.solution: Melanoma is the aggressive skin cancer that has higher propensity for lymphatic and systemic metastases. However, Uvea does not have lymphatics, hence Uveal melanoma does not have lymphatic spread, rather they present later with liver metastases.

questions.text: All of the following has precursor malignant lesions except
questions.solution: Basal cell cancer is the only skin cancer which arises de novo and does not have any precursor lesions. Precursor lesions for squamous cell cancer include actinic keratoses and bowen's disease. For melanoma, Dysplastic nevus, spitz nevus and junctional nevus.

questions.text: Delivery of larger doses per fraction(>2 Gy) of radiation over a shorter overall time is
questions.solution: Fractionation is the process of dividing the total radiation dose into smaller, equal doses that are delivered over time. Accelerated fractionation is delivery of standard fraction given in a shorter overall time, by giving twice daily. Hyperfractionation is delivery of higher total radiation dose via smaller than standard dose. Hypofractionation is delivery of larger doses per fraction over a shorter overall time.

questions.text: Which variant of Malignant Melanoma exhibit Neurotropism?
questions.solution: Desmoplastic melanoma is the type of melanoma more common in head and neck regions and it exhibit the property of neurotropism, which can be associated with recurrence.
